com.leakyabstractions.result

Class Results

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.leakyabstractions.result.Results

  • public class Results
extends Object
    This class consists exclusively of static methods that operate on or return Result instances.
    Author:
    Guillermo Calvo
    See Also:
    com.leakyabstractions.result

      • ofNullable

        public static <S,F> Result<S,F> ofNullable(S value,
                                           F failure)
        If the given value is not null, returns a new successful result with it; otherwise returns a new failed result with failure.
        Type Parameters:
        S - the success type of the result
        F - the failure type of the result
        Parameters:
        value - the value to check if null
        failure - the failure value to use in case value is null
        Returns:
        the new result
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if both value and failure are null

      • ofNullable

        public static <S,F> Result<S,F> ofNullable(S value,
                                           Supplier<? extends F> failureSupplier)
        If the given value is not null, returns a new successful result with it; otherwise returns a new failed result with a value produced by the given supplier function.
        Type Parameters:
        S - the success type of the result
        F - the failure type of the result
        Parameters:
        value - the value to check if null
        failureSupplier - the supplier function that produces a failure value
        Returns:
        the new result
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if both value and failureSupplier are null, or if failureSupplier returns null

      • ofOptional

        public static <S,F> Result<S,F> ofOptional(Optional<S> optional,
                                           F failure)
        If the given optional is not empty, returns a new successful result with its value; otherwise returns a new failed result with failure.
        Type Parameters:
        S - the success type of the result
        F - the failure type of the result
        Parameters:
        optional - the optional to check if empty
        failure - the failure value to use in case optional is empty
        Returns:
        the new result
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if optional is null; or if optional is empty and failure is null

      • ofOptional

        public static <S,F> Result<S,F> ofOptional(Optional<S> optional,
                                           Supplier<? extends F> failureSupplier)
        If the given optional is not empty, returns a new successful result with its value; otherwise returns a new failed result with a value produced by the given supplier function.
        Type Parameters:
        S - the success type of the result
        F - the failure type of the result
        Parameters:
        optional - the optional to check if empty
        failureSupplier - the supplier function that produces a failure value
        Returns:
        the new result
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if optional is null; or if optional is empty and failureSupplier is null; or if failureSupplier returns null

      • wrap

        public static <S> Result<S,Exception> wrap(Callable<S> callable)
        If the given callable produces a success value, returns a new successful result with it; otherwise returns a new failed result with the exception thrown by callable.
        Type Parameters:
        S - the success type of the result
        Parameters:
        callable - the task that produces a success value, or throws an exception if unable to do so
        Returns:
        the new result
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if callable is null
        API Note:
        If callable returns null then a new failed result with a NullPointerException will be returned.

      • wrap

        public static <S,F> Result<S,F> wrap(Callable<S> callable,
                                     Function<? super Exception,F> exceptionMapper)
        If the given callable produces a success value, returns a new successful result with it; otherwise returns a new failed result with a value produced by the given mapping function.

        The mapping function will be applied to the exception thrown by callable to produce the failure value.

        Type Parameters:
        S - the success type of the result
        F - the failure type of the result
        Parameters:
        callable - the task that produces a success value, or throws an exception if unable to do so
        exceptionMapper - the mapping function that produces a failure value
        Returns:
        the new result
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if callable is null, or if callable throws an exception and exceptionMapper is null, or if exceptionMapper returns null
        API Note:
        If callable returns null then the mapping function will be applied to an instance of NullPointerException.

      • lazy

        public static <S,F> Result<S,F> lazy(Supplier<Result<S,F>> supplier)
        Creates a new lazy result based on the given result supplier.

        Lazy results can be manipulated just like any other result; they will try to defer the invocation of the given supplier as long as possible. The purpose is to encapsulate an expensive operation that may be omitted if there's no actual need to examine the result.

        Lazy results can be filtered and transformed without actually performing the expensive operation:

        • filter
        • map
        • mapSuccess
        • mapFailure
        • flatMap
        • flatMapSuccess
        • flatMapFailure

        On the other hand, the supplier will be invoked if any of these terminal operations is performed on a lazy result:

        • isSuccess
        • isFailure
        • orElse
        • orElseMap
        • orElseThrow
        • orElseThrow(Function)
        • getFailureOrElseThrow
        • optional
        • optionalFailure
        • stream
        • streamFailure

        Finally, conditional actions will be performed immediately unless they are lazy too:

        • ifSuccess
        • ifSuccessOrElse
        • ifFailure

        Once a lazy result retrieves the supplied result, all future operations will be performed immediately and the returned Result objects should not be lazy.

        Type Parameters:
        S - the success type of the result
        F - the failure type of the result
        Parameters:
        supplier - the function that supplies the actual result
        Returns:
        the new lazy result
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if supplier is null
        See Also:
        lazy(Consumer)
        API Note:
        The supplier is guaranteed to be invoked at most once. If it throws an exception or returns null then the behavior of the lazy result will be undefined.

      • lazy

        public static <T> Consumer<T> lazy(Consumer<T> consumer)
        Creates a new lazy consumer based on a regular one.

        Lazy consumers encapsulate actions that depend on success or failure and can be safely deferred or even completely ignored if a lazy result is never evaluated. They are intended to be passed as parameters to:

        • ifSuccess
        • ifSuccessOrElse
        • ifFailure

        These actions will execute immediately if passed to non-lazy results.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the input to the action
        Parameters:
        consumer - the action to be applied to this result's success value
        Returns:
        the new lazy consumer
        See Also:
        lazy(Supplier)
